item.title: Bar Plots
item.description: This type of data visualiztion is my personal favorite. I hope you like learning about it too! Let’s make sure to install the proper pakages. library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) This example will look at the team homerun totals for all the MLB teams in 1980. query<-"SELECT name,HR FROM Teams WHERE yearID=1980 ORDER BY HR " result<-sqldf(query) result$name<-factor(result$name,levels=result$name) It is important to let the system know how the data should appear in, by saving the command as factor.

item.title: Histograms
item.description: Welcome back we are going to try a Histogram example! Alright, in this example we will look at the weights of MLB players through the Master table in the Lahman database.` Make sure you have the following applications ready to work with: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) This request uses the Master table to gather its data. query<-"SELECT weight FROM Master" result<-sqldf(query) Let’s try it out using our handy tool ggplot2! ggplot()+ geom_histogram(data=result,aes(x=weight),color="blue",fill="white",bins=60)+ ggtitle("Distribution of Baseball Player Bodyweight")+ xlab("Weight of player")+ ylab("Number of players") ## Warning: Removed 854 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin).

item.title: Scatterplot Fun
item.description: Let’s learn how to create our own scatter plot! First, we need to install the following pakages and store them by putting them into library. library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) Let’s try to find some information using the packages we just installed. We are going to try to find career homeruns and strikeouts from players who had more than 400 homeruns. query<-"SELECT playerID,sum(HR),sum(SO) FROM Batting GROUP BY playerID HAVING sum(HR)>400" sqldf(query) ## playerID sum(HR) sum(SO) ## 1 aaronha01 755 1383 ## 2 bagweje01 449 1558 ## 3 bankser01 512 1236 ## 4 beltrad01 445 1584 ## 5 beltrca01 421 1693 ## 6 bondsba01 762 1539 ## 7 cabremi01 446 1516 ## 8 cansejo01 462 1942 ## 9 dawsoan01 438 1509 ## 10 delgaca01 473 1745 ## 11 dunnad01 462 2379 ## 12 evansda01 414 1410 ## 13 foxxji01 534 1311 ## 14 gehrilo01 493 790 ## 15 giambja01 440 1572 ## 16 gonzaju03 434 1273 ## 17 griffke02 630 1779 ## 18 guerrvl01 449 985 ## 19 jacksre01 563 2597 ## 20 jonesan01 434 1748 ## 21 jonesch06 468 1409 ## 22 killeha01 573 1699 ## 23 kingmda01 442 1816 ## 24 konerpa01 439 1391 ## 25 mantlmi01 536 1710 ## 26 matheed01 512 1487 ## 27 mayswi01 660 1526 ## 28 mccovwi01 521 1550 ## 29 mcgrifr01 493 1882 ## 30 mcgwima01 583 1596 ## 31 murraed02 504 1516 ## 32 musiast01 475 696 ## 33 ortizda01 541 1750 ## 34 ottme01 511 896 ## 35 palmera01 569 1348 ## 36 piazzmi01 427 1113 ## 37 pujolal01 591 1053 ## 38 ramirma02 555 1813 ## 39 ripkeca01 431 1305 ## 40 robinfr02 586 1532 ## 41 rodrial01 696 2287 ## 42 ruthba01 714 1330 ## 43 schmimi01 548 1883 ## 44 sheffga01 509 1171 ## 45 snidedu01 407 1237 ## 46 soriaal01 412 1803 ## 47 sosasa01 609 2306 ## 48 stargwi01 475 1936 ## 49 teixema01 409 1441 ## 50 thomafr04 521 1397 ## 51 thomeji01 612 2548 ## 52 willibi01 426 1046 ## 53 willite01 521 709 ## 54 winfida01 465 1686 ## 55 yastrca01 452 1393 Now that you have the information, save it as result so that we can make a scatter plot.

item.title: Time Series
item.description: Here is another cool data visualization example using a times series graph Just like the last post we have to make sure we dowload all the proper pakages and put them into library. library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) In this post we will view Babe Ruth’s homeruns over his career in baseball. query<-"SELECT yearID,HR FROM Batting WHERE playerID='ruthba01'" result<-sqldf(query) Now the best part, the graph! Again, using ggplot2 we will graph the line and points of the information we just collected, to form a time series.
